quest.name: Dead but Not Gone
journal: The Wood Wailers are confounded by a recent find in the Palace of the Dead.

During a recent expedition, the Wood Wailers were shocked to discover notes they believe to be penned by Nybeth Obdilord, the dread sorcerer who raised the Palace of the Dead. Knowing you had the misfortune of meeting him in person, they would consult with you regarding the contents of the documents. An expeditionary awaits you by the entrance to Issom–Har.

The expeditionary explains to you that he and his fellow Wood Wailers are puzzled by the strange script of the documents, which he surmises originated in a foreign land. E–Una–Kotor, having communed with the elementals, believes they are not from another land, but another world entirely. Taking the notes in hand, visions of Nybeth and Edda suddenly flash before your eyes. It would appear that his true purpose in building the palace was to master the art of resurrection, giving him the power to bring his lover back from the dead. E–Una–Kotor finds such a motive implausible, but with the dark sorcerer slain, the truth now remains buried in the hallowed grounds beneath Issom–Har.

dialogue.name: WOODWAILER01556
dialogue.text: Madam!Sir! A moment, if you would. Are you not the adventurer who felled the dark sorcerer in the ruins? It is you, thank the Twelve! We are in immediate need of your assistance!

dialogue.name: WOODWAILER01556
dialogue.text: Allow me to explain. On a recent reconnaissance mission, our men unearthed documents we believe were written by the selfsame sorcerer you encountered down in the labyrinth. As we have been desperately searching for more insight into this man and the unspeakable acts he committed, the importance of this discovery cannot be overstated.

dialogue.name: WOODWAILER01556
dialogue.text: The documents have thus far proved beyond our comprehension, but now that you are here─why, who better to help us decipher their contents than the womanman who braved the depths of those fell ruins to confront the fiend!

dialogue.name: WOODWAILER01556
dialogue.text: One of my fellow expeditionaries will be waiting for you at Issom–Har with the aforementioned documents. E–Una–Kotor communes with the elementals as we speak─he, too, shall join you anon.

dialogue.name: WOODWAILER01556
dialogue.text: Pray make haste to Issom–Har. E–Una–Kotor shall meet with you there anon.

dialogue.name: WOODWAILER02338
dialogue.text: Well met, adventurer. Your cooperation in this matter is much appreciated. We had hoped these documents would serve to enlighten us regarding the nature and motives of the dread sorcerer Nybeth, but I fear there is a rub...

dialogue.name: WOODWAILER02338
dialogue.text: They are written in a foreign script that is entirely unfamiliar to our eyes. We know not where to begin in determining the origin of these odd glyphs, let alone deciphering their meaning.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: 'Tis little surprise they are not familiar to you. If that most curious aetheric signature is aught to judge by, I would surmise those papers, and the man who penned them, hail from a world not our own.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: Forename Surname... Kan–E–Senna tells me that you possess a special gift─one that grants you a preternatural insight to the true nature of those around you.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: From my understanding, this power is not one to be invoked at will. But having exposed yourself to the otherworldly presence of Nybeth, mayhap... Might you take these documents into hand, and see if aught appears before your mind's eye?

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: No, no, no! This is all wrong! Her soul will not remain bound to the flesh. It is as if she is rejecting her corporeal form. Mayhap the vessel is too weak...?

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: But that cannot be! A passionate spirit is possessed of inexhaustible stores of aether, and hers is by far the most strong-willed of my specimens. She should have the strength to remain tethered to this realm in perpetuity!

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: But no...! Not even a glimmer of life in her body! Could it possibly be...? That her spirit would seek to return to the aetherial sea of its own accord...!? Preposterous!

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: Would you be so foolish as to welcome the hollow embrace of eternal sleep? To sate yourself with memories of your worthless life as you drift off into the void?

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: Hmph... And what would you say, old friend? Would you blather about the virtue of accepting death, and extol her pure-hearted wish to rest beside her lost love?

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: Hah! I think not! My Edda would never be blinded to the truth by some starry-eyed fantasy! No, a spirit as strong as hers would never fade so meekly into nothingness.

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: Only a fool would yearn for death, to lay quietly within that mortiferous shade! And that is why I press on─to realize the dreams of all who came before me, and all who will come after!

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: And yet... It would seem your spirit remains entangled with that of another. Not your lost love, no─but the one who besmirched your soul with these vulgar notions of accepting─nay, embracing that vain slumber!

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: It's that rat sniffing about in my maze, isn't it? I can still smell herhis stench upon you. And the repugnant foetor of the...admiration you feel for herhim.

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: Let us conduct an experiment, shall we? Yesss, a test of loyalty─one that shall also serve to purge these halls of shehe who would dare interfere with my most noble aims!

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: Go forth, my sweet Edda! Go forth and seek out your beloved hero.

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: Give herhim the gift of death you would seek yourself, and in the doing, free yourself from the shackles that bind your spirit so!

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: Soon... Yes, soon the secrets of eternal life will be mine! Will be...ours.

dialogue.name: NYBETHOBDILORD
dialogue.text: Then, my love...I shall pull back the veil, and pluck your soul from the wastelands of the damned. And we shall be as one again, inseparable forevermore! Muahahaha!

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: You return to us, Forename. Pray tell, what did you see?

dialogue.name: WOODWAILER02388
dialogue.text: This dread sorcerer sought to bring his beloved back from the dead? That is what impelled him to torment countless souls in his experiments down in those shadowy depths?

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: While I cannot say for certain, I would rather not believe that such a simple, innocent desire could give birth to such blasphemous deeds.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: Nor am I inclined to believe that resurrection of the manner he suggests is even possible. Nay, I find it far more likely he meant only to play some cruel game with poor Edda, preying on the love she bore for her friends.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: Even if there was once an onze of compassion in that monster's heart, one thing is certain─his unholy quest to rejoin body and spirit has disturbed the balance of the Twelveswood.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: Longing to reunite with a lost love is one thing, but to knowingly sacrifice the lives of countless others... 'Tis little wonder that such an odious act would incur the wrath of the elementals.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: As a Padjal, I cannot sit idly by as such terrors endanger our forest home.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: From the pages of that fiend, I could sense naught but an all-consuming obsession with life and death, and a hunger for the shadows.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: You confronted the dread necromancer in the heart of the labyrinth. Tell me─what did you make of him and his goals?

dialogue.name: Q2
dialogue.text: What will you say?

dialogue.name: A2
dialogue.text: He was a depraved monster who saw the dead as mere playthings.

dialogue.name: A2
dialogue.text: He was a twisted, pitiful creature driven by false ideals.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: I daresay you have the right of it. No matter what his stated aim, disturbing the peace of the departed is a heinous crime indeed.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: Pitiful indeed. He chose to flee from death─from the natural order of existence─to go where no man should tread. I daresay his soul is unlikely to ever find peace.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: Ah, pray forgive me. It was untoward of me to ask you to speculate on the aspirations of a madman after only a short glimpse into his past.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: At the very least, we can take comfort in knowing that Nybeth and his ill ambitions are no more. Now, we must see to it that the labyrinth is purged of the abominable creations that run rampant within, that the wayward souls still trapped there may at long last find peace.

dialogue.name: EUNAKOTOR
dialogue.text: When the Palace of the Dead is at last cleansed of the sorcerer's taint, I will invoke the power of the elementals to seal closed the ingress, that none may ever be lost to its unholy halls again.
